pull.title: contrib: Fixup verify-binaries OS platform parsing
pull.body:
Closes #30145.

This PR solves two major issues in the `parse_version_string` function of verify-binaries:
1. `-aarch64` binaries cannot be specifically downloaded. The -platform string gets interpreted as a release candidate that doesn't exist due to containing sub-string "rc".
2. Specifying a platform with a "-" in the name causes the parser to ignore both "-platform" AND "-rcN" and download the potentially wrong (non-rc) version for every platform. This also prevented specifying just one platform binary the user wished to download.

It also updates the accompanying `test.py` to cover problem two and adds two examples that were formerly broken to `README.md` to show what is now possible. Including the most useful case of downloading only 1 specific platform's binary.

This improves the Bitcoin verify-binaries tools user experience by not:
1. Failing to download for inexplicable reasons,
2. Downloading more files than what the user told it to, or in the worst case
3. Downloading only the wrong files.

* A test was added to cover the command `verify-binaries/verify.py pub 22.0-x86_64-linux-gnu.tar.gz` which checks that _bitcoin-22.0-x86_64-linux-gnu.tar.gz_ downloads successfully AND ONLY _bitcoin-22.0-x86_64-linux-gnu.tar.gz_ downloads.
* The steps to reproduce each bug are in the referenced issue #30145. Explanation of the potential issue as well as reasoning for the way the bug was fixed are in my commit descriptions.
* This delivers the promised feature of "only download the binaries for a certain platform", by allowing strings with '-' to be accepted, allowing for single file downloads for any specific platform which was not always possible before.
* Removes 6 lines of code from the offending `parse_version_string` function, while fixing the bugs/errors, and extending the functionality to be practical for users with slow connections.

Thanks for reading my PR. I look forward to getting this helpful tool in its best shape yet.

Log of this branch passing the new test.py:
```
python3 test.py
âœ“ 'Nonexistent version should fail' passed
âœ“ 'Malformed version should fail' passed
âœ“ '--min-good-sigs 20 should fail' passed
- testing verification (22.0-x86_64-linux-gnu.tar.gz)
âœ“ '22.0-x86_64-linux-gnu.tar.gz should succeed' passed
- testing verification (22.0)
âœ“ '22.0 should succeed' passed
```

Log of master failing the new test.py:
```
python3 test.py
âœ“ 'Nonexistent version should fail' passed
âœ“ 'Malformed version should fail' passed
âœ“ '--min-good-sigs 20 should fail' passed
- testing verification (22.0-x86_64-linux-gnu.tar.gz)
âœ“ '22.0-x86_64-linux-gnu.tar.gz should succeed' passed
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/ben/Documents/GitHub/bitcoin/contrib/verify-binaries/test.py", line 74, in <module>
    main()
  File "/home/ben/Documents/GitHub/bitcoin/contrib/verify-binaries/test.py", line 27, in main
    assert len(v) == 1
           ^^^^^^^^^^^
AssertionError
```

verification.payload:
tree 54cbe5c1236f51998bfd828e57c9e2f5d313b4bb
parent a786fd2041913d82ca90b561de309421bd24e41b
author Ben Westgate <BenWestgate@protonmail.com> 1716303724 -0500
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1716303724 -0500

Fix version string parsing bugs in verify.py

Fix version string parsing bugs in verify.py

`VERSION_EXAMPLE` was updated to include a string the tool handles properly now.

When the "-platform" specified contains a "-", the previous code ignored it and the "-rc" entirely. By using list slices os version strings with more dashes can be specified. like "linux-gnu" or "x86_64-linux-gnu". The "-" are replaced with join.

When the "-platform" specified was "aarch64" the parser interpreted it as a release candidate version number because it contains the sub-string "rc", causing all downloads to fail for that platform. By matching "-rc" this is avoided. Slices are used in that conditional to avoid reference out of range errors if there is no "-" in `version_str`.

When "-rcN" is specified in `parts[1]` version_os is reassigned to "-".join(parts[2:]) to remove the '-rcN' prefix.

I wanted these changes because I want to ONLY download one bitcoin core binary as my Tor connection is sometimes slow. These changes make `verify.py pub` more intuitive, robust and versatile.

events.message:
Fix version string parsing bugs in verify.py

Fix version string parsing bugs in verify.py

`VERSION_EXAMPLE` was updated to include a string the tool handles properly now.

When the "-platform" specified contains a "-", the previous code ignored it and the "-rc" entirely. By using list slices os version strings with more dashes can be specified. like "linux-gnu" or "x86_64-linux-gnu". The "-" are replaced with join.

When the "-platform" specified was "aarch64" the parser interpreted it as a release candidate version number because it contains the sub-string "rc", causing all downloads to fail for that platform. By matching "-rc" this is avoided. Slices are used in that conditional to avoid reference out of range errors if there is no "-" in `version_str`.

When "-rcN" is specified in `parts[1]` version_os is reassigned to "-".join(parts[2:]) to remove the '-rcN' prefix.

I wanted these changes because I want to ONLY download one bitcoin core binary as my Tor connection is sometimes slow. These changes make `verify.py pub` more intuitive, robust and versatile.

events.message:
Update README.md with examples made possible after bugfix

Update README.md with examples now possible after bugfix

Added example: `./contrib/verify-binaries/verify.py --json pub 23.0-rc5-linux-gnu` to show release candidates now will work with -platform strings containing "-" and the string provided can be from the middle of the full match.

Added example: `./contrib/verify-binaries/verify.py pub 25.2-x86_64-linux-gnu` to show the platform can now be provided specifically enough to download only a single binary. 

This is very useful on slow connections so I thought people should see it as the first example for "only download the binaries for a certain platform". Downloading one file is intuitively what most will think "certain platform" meant and this branch delivers on that expectation.

tree fcbed641d1984e94707cd2bf16f0cfb178d80709
parent d1265903da910fdc805d38ccc9fc1424b954bdaa
author Ben Westgate <BenWestgate@protonmail.com> 1716315530 -0500
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1716315530 -0500

Update test.py to cover the platform parsing bug from #30145

After fixing #30145 in this branch, contrib/verify-binaries/verify.py can accept an entire filename filter for its "-platform" parameter so let us test that first to make sure it succeeds, only downloads one file and the file has good signatures and the correct hash.

The new test is equivalent to running `verify.py pub 22.0-x86_64-linux-gnu.tar.gz` which should grab only the requested platform's binary.
    
It is placed before the existing <version> only verification as it is a faster test and possibly easier to break.

events.body: @DrahtBot: I am fairly sure this PR is NOT a consensus change. It's a bugfix to a download verification tool script. Replace that label with a more accurate one.

@BenWestgate I believe this is a typo in the documentation, fixed in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/30150. (You can change the title yourself to `contrib:` and the bot will pick it up at some point.)

rename.from: script: Fix errors in verify-binaries/verify.py OS platform parsing, update test.py & docs

events.body: Merge commits in pull requests are discouraged in this repo, please squash your commits according to https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#squashing-commits
There are also similar changes in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/28418 but I didn't check this PR yet to see if they are the same.
